thread.title: You'll never see the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge holding hands in public - here's why
thread.title_full: You'll never see the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge holding hands in public - here's why

author: Zahra Mulroy
title: You'll never see the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge holding hands in public - here's why
text:
Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge and Prince William (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Royalists and romantics whooped with delight when the Cambridges gave each other a chaste kiss on the balcony of Buckingham Palace on their wedding day five years ago. 
While not everyone is a born hand-holder, since then, Kate and Will have kept the PDAs to a minimum. 
With exception of their embracing at Team GB's Olympic cycling victory, and the official photos of them holding hands as they climbed to the Tiger's Nest Monastery in Bhutan, images of them being physically affectionate are few and far between. 
The couple are still young, in love and clearly have a great time together. Then again, they are Royal - so live by a different set of rules to us mere mortals. They do have their hands full here (Photo: Getty) 
Could it be their status which dictates a certain amount of decorum? Well, yes and no. 
Whatever your opinion of the Royal Family, they probably still have the same impulses as the rest of the general public. Read More There's a specific reason why the Duchess of Cambridge carries her clutch bag with both hands The Duke and Duchess arrive at the BAFTAs (Photo: AFP) 
Interestingly, should Kate and Wills feel the urge to hold hands, there are no rules which say they can't do so when on public engagements. 
Instead, the founder of Beaumont Etiquette, Myka Meier told People : 
"There is no actual etiquette or royal protocol that says the couple must refrain from PDA [public displays of affection]. Read More The simple reason Prince William never wears a wedding ring Whatever it is they are doing here, it's not hand holding (Photo: PA) 
"The likely reasoning is more that while travelling on a tour such as the India trip, technically the couple are working representatives of British Monarchy. 
"The couple are likely to show very little PDA, if any, to remain professional during their designated roles abroad." 
So there you go. 
It's because being Royal is technically a job - and would you start grabbing your colleagues' hands during office hours? Like us on Facebook
